"Virtue is pleasure," said a Grecian sage,</br>"And is the most virtuous, the happiest far;"</br>A nobler sentiment upon the page</br>Of Revelation sparkles like a star.</br>Men have done much his pure intent to mar,</br>Whom many follow, and but few obey;</br>But truth will laugh, however fools may jar,—</br>Tired Reason shall at length spurn Falsehood's sway,</br>Exulting like the sun, when storms have roll'd away.

"Who seeks the general weal, secures his own"—</br>Such the arch-precept of the latest school</br>Of Ethical discovery — alone</br>Varying in sound from the Athenian's rule.</br>The gentle creed of Nazareth is full</br>Of a like spirit — fairer and more free—</br>Then cease to cry Eureka!  haste and cool</br>Thy crazed disciples' neophytic glee,</br>Utilitarian Priest — word-wedding Jeremy!

Who doubts the maxim of the Benthamites?</br>'Tis co-existent with the human soul,</br>And of its shrine one of the sacred lights—</br>Though oft-times clouded by the gross control</br>Of the dust's opaque demon — he, the sole</br>Keeper of the multitudinous cells,</br>Wherein earth's anticks, miserably droll,</br>Make mouths at Heaven to smirking Folly's bells,</br>Shaming the voiceless brute that in the desert dwells.

In morals 'tis an axiom — here — even here—</br>Upon the slippery bank and shoal of time,</br>With hell-fire in abeyance — noon-day clear,—</br>The worst like not to be the sport of crime,</br>Drench'd with their own foul vintage — every clime</br>To sins peculiar adds their punishment—</br>The unity of Justice is sublime—</br>I should have said of Mercy — for 'tis meant</br>To urge them back to peace, whose steps are woward bent.

And dismal were this globe were it not so!</br>'Tis bad enough; but it is Paradise,</br>Compared to what it would be, were there no</br>Terrestrial scourge for the salt blood of Vice—</br>Lust, flame-respiring, homicidal Pride,</br>And all our household devils running wild,</br>Would roam, high-fed and rampant, far and wide,</br>Making that hideous, yet but half defiled,</br>Trampling each shoot of good on arid life that smiled.

Of sermonizing we have had enough—</br>If this besotted land will not awaken,</br>It is not framed of penetrable stuff—</br>Cobbett himself hath to the rostrum taken,</br>Teaching Britannia how to save her bacon—</br>Cool Owen lauds his parallelogram</br>With pertinacity, by sneers unshaken—</br>And would therein all sorts of people cram,</br>Penning, in common fold, ass, lion, wolf, and lamb.

But Ill will keep its throne, till doomsday steal,</br>Thief-like, upon the prowlers of the world;</br>They who to abstract equity appeal,</br>Will find the general lip derisive, curl'd.</br>In vain, Philanthropy!  thy flag's unfurl'd</br>On distant Harmony's Millennian heights;</br>Dissension's blazing brands shall still be hurl'd,</br>And maugre all that honest Bentham writes,</br>Laws will be Knavery's tools, and suitors hapless wights.

Marshal, Old Truepenny!  a chosen band,</br>And let them furnish practice to thy preaching—</br>Actions, the shallowest brain can understand,</br>Examples, the sure mode of moral teaching—</br>Proclaim a truce to threatening and beseeching,</br>In streets and highways plant each partisan,</br>Purified from the itch for over-reaching,</br>Sworn foes to every ceco-selfish plan,</br>Warm and unflinching friends to the old house of man.

And then — "God speed the cause!"  pray I for one—</br>A worthier never link'd true hearts together—</br>The faint may fall before the harvest's done—</br>The stoutest hardly brave the wayward weather.</br>But more than Mammon's gem, or Honour's feather,</br>Shall the survivors of the field repay,</br>When Sorrow's children round a glad hearth gather,</br>To speak of those who chased their griefs away—</br>Who flinty Custom crush'd that ground them in the clay.</br>
